awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CEDAR--A Long-term Investigation of Auroral and Tidal Forcing of E-region Thermospheric Winds at High Latitudes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will use an 8-year data set from the Poker Flat Incoherent Scatter Radar (PFISR) to investigate the climatology and variability of high-latitude lower thermospheric winds. The analysis will address questions of the relative contribution of energy and momentum transfer from different sources. A long-term database of wind profiles will be developed and made available to the community to be used for testing of complex models.

This study will advance the understanding of ion-neutral coupling and energy, mass and momentum transfer between the magnetosphere, thermosphere, and atmosphere, and will investigate auroral effects on lower thermospheric winds. Case studies will be used to examine events of strong atmospheric or auroral forcing. The long-term data base will provide information about trends in lower thermospheric winds and which forcing mechanisms are most responsible for long-term variability.

por.por_cntn:
Summary of Effort:

We proposed to use a nearly continuously sampled dataset from the Poker Flat Incoherent Scatter Radar (PFISR) spanning 10 years (from 2007 to present) to investigate the climatology and variability of high-latitude E-region thermospheric winds. Of particular interest are the intermediate driving scenarios, where it is unclear whether magnetospheric driving from above or atmospheric driving from below are shaping the observed neutral winds.

We specifically proposed to address three scientific questions:
1. What are the characteristics and range of responses of lower thermospheric winds to auroral and background atmospheric forcing at high latitudes? 

2. What effect does structure in high-latitude lower thermospheric winds have on the modulation of energy dissipation through Joule heating?

3. What are the properties of vertical neutral winds and how common are large vertical winds in the lower thermosphere?

Our methodology is to develop a long-term database of E-region thermospheric wind profiles and Joule heating, undertake correlation analysis to categorize background forcing and auroral effects on lower thermospheric winds, and use case studies to examine events of strong atmospheric or auroral forcing.  We expect that the primary product to the community from this study will be a long term data base of E-region neutral wind profiles that can be used independently or assimilated into the Horizontal Wind Model, and scientific publications.

 

Key Outcomes:

This investigation produced one of the largest ISR derive database of E-region neutral winds to date spanning from 2010-2019. These data are posted on Zenodo (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5781251). The database not only includes the neutral winds, but also the electric fields, conductivities, neutral drag terms (Hall and Pedersen), and some associated forces (Coriolis, Lorentz, centrifugal).

The outcome of this investigation primarily addressed scientific question #2 and #1.  This investigation produced 2 peer-reviewed publication, contributions to 1 book chapter, and contributions to Rafael Mesquita's doctoral disseration.  The peer reviewed publications focused very heavily on Science Question #2 above.  Our results have also been used by a number of other investigations, with future publications pending.

The majority of the effort was data processing and data analysis, which was accomplished by a postdoctoral research associate and a graduate student. Two undergraduate students at Clemson University were supported by this effort and gained exposure to incoherent scatter radar.

 

 

Significant Results:

One of the key findings from our investigation was quantifying how seasonal, geomagnetic, and the solar cycle impacts the E-region Joule heating rate.  This paper, written by postdoc Weijia Zhan, was an example of the kind of investigation that was very well suited for this investigation using the long-duration database of PFISR observations.  The most significant result from this investigation was that the Joule heating rate follows the seasonal changes of the electric field predominantly.  Although this conclusion may be somewhat obvious, this paper was one of the first ISR investigations, and one of the first investigations in general, to examine seasonal effects on the Joule heating rate.  
  
The other peer reviewed Joule heating paper discussed the technique and we compared our observations to an appropriate previous investigation, namely, Aikio et al., 2012 and Cai et al., 2013.  We found some differences in the MLT occurance of the peak Joule heating rate.  We found during Fall 2015 which had similar conditions to the interval investigated by Aikio et al., 2012, we found the peak Joule heating rate occurred during the evening/dusk sector.  Some of these findings could be attributed to the different geographic location of PFISR relative to the EISCAT ISRs. 
  
The book chapter included some results of Joule heating from PFISR and some of the initial results we had produced.  These results were illustrative of the Joule heating response we observed at PFISR and served to help understand the nature of energy transfer through Joule heating.
 
Publications:
Zhan, W., Kaeppler, S. R., Reimer, A., & Varney, R. (2021). Seasonal and solar cycle dependence of energy transfer rates in the auroral E-region. Journal of Geophysical Research: Space Physics, 126, e2021JA029719. https://doi.org/10.1029/2021JA029719
  
Zhan, W., Kaeppler, S. R., Larsen, M. F., Reimer, A., & Varney, R. (2021). An investigation of auroral E region energy exchange using Poker Flat Incoherent Scatter Radar observations during fall equinox conditions. Journal of Geophysical Research: Space Physics, 126, e2021JA029371. https://doi.org/10.1029/2021JA029371
  
Stephen R. Kaeppler, Delores J. Knipp, Olga P. Verkhoglyadova, Liam M. Kilcommons, Weijia Zhan. (2022) Chapter 5 - Electromagnetic energy input and dissipation. Cross-Scale Coupling and Energy Transfer in the Magnetosphere-ionosphere-thermosphere System, Editor(s): Yukitoshi Nishimura, Olga Verkhoglyadova, Yue Deng, Shun-Rong Zhang, Elsevier, Pages 301-355, ISBN 9780128213667, https://doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-12-821366-7.00006-8.
